Tolan]] | designated_nrhp_type= July 31, 2003<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=-479586368&ResourceType=Building |title=Allen County Courthouse|accessdate=2008-07-23|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing|publisher=National Park Service}}</ref> | added = May 28, 1976 | governing_body = Local | refnum=76000031<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} The '''Allen County Courthouse''' in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] is one of 37 [[United States]] [[National Historic Landmark]]s in the state of [[Indiana]]. It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1976 and was designated a National Historic Landmark in 2003. ==History== Designed by [[Brentwood S. Tolan]], construction began in 1897, the cornerstone was laid November 17, 1897. The building was dedicated September 23, 1902 with a final cost of $817,553.59. On September 23, 2002, the building was re-dedicated on its [[centennial]] after a seven-year restoration effort, which cost $8.6 million.<ref>(2002-09-23). Restoration does justiceâ€”The finished work awes and amazes visitors. ''The News-Sentinel''. Retrieved on 2009-07-25.</ref> ==Architectural details== The [[Beaux-Arts architecture]]-style structure includes such features as four 25 by {{convert|45|ft|m|sing=on}} murals by Charles Holloway, twenty-eight different kinds of [[scagiola]] covering {{convert|15000|sqft|m2}}, [[Bas relief|bas-relief]]s and [[art glass]]. Each of the five court rooms has its own color scheme.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} Atop the building is a {{convert|255|ft|m|sing=on}}-high copper-clad domed rotunda, itself topped by a {{convert|14|ft|m|sing=on}} statue [[Weather vane|wind vane]] of [[Liberty (goddess)|Lady Liberty]]. The larger than life statue has feet that would wear a woman's [[shoe size]] of 28.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} The building materials include Bedford Limestone and [[Vermont]] [[granite]] with [[Italy|Italian]] [[marble]] details. A tunnel was constructed to connect the Courthouse with the City-County Building located across the street. The Courthouse also houses a fallout shelter underground. The skylights originally built into the building were covered during [[World War II]] and replaced with artificial light.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} The 2001 National Historic Landmark Nomination says in its opening paragraph: "An elaborate combination of Greek, Roman, and Renaissance influences, the massive courthouse reflects the exuberant ambition of late nineteenth century America."<ref name="nrhpinv2">{{Cite book|title={{PDFlink|[http://pdfhost.focus.nps.gov/docs/NHLS/Text/76000031.pdf National Historic Landmark Nomination: Allen County Courthouse]|32 KB}}|date=May 5, 2001 |author=Christine Wiltberger, Carolyn Pitts, and Patty Henry |publisher=National Park Service}} and {{PDFlink|[http://pdfhost.focus.nps.gov/docs/NHLS/Photos/76000031.pdf ''Accompanying 52 page of photos and credits, exterior and interior, from 1999 and undated'']|32 KB}}</ref> <gallery> File:USA-Allen County Courthouse 7697.JPG|Interior of the courthouse rotunda File:Allen County Courthouse.JPG|Exterior of the courthouse rotunda File:Allen County Courthouse 7701.JPG|''[[Scagliola]]'' in the Allen County Courthouse File:Allen County Courthouse 7739.JPG|''[[Scagliola]]'' in the Allen County Courthouse File:Allen Co.jpg|[[Pediment]] and [[finial|finial figure]] </gallery> ==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in Fort Wayne]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Registered Historic Places}} {{NHLs in IN}} [[Category:County courthouses in Indiana]] [[Category:National Historic Landmarks in Indiana]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1902]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Fort Wayne, Indiana]] [[Category:Clock towers in Indiana]]
